title: 5 Signs Your Pet Needs Urgent Care
excerpt: Learn how to spot the subtle warning signs that your furry friend might need immediate veterinary attention.
content:
Our pets can't tell us when something is wrong, so it's up to us to notice the signs. In this guide, Dr. Hamilton breaks down the 5 critical symptoms you should never ignore...

1. Difficulty Breathing: If your pet is panting without exercise or struggling for breath, this is an emergency.
2. Seizures: Any seizure activity requires immediate vet care.
3. Sudden Collapse: Even if they recover quickly, this could indicate heart issues.
4. Vomiting/Diarrhea: If persistent for more than 24 hours or containing blood.
5. Difficulty Urinating: Especially in male cats, this is life-threatening.

Always err on the side of caution. If you are unsure, call our 24/7 triage line immediately.
author: Dr. Richard Hamilton

title: Nutrition 101: The Raw Food Debate
excerpt: Is a raw diet right for your dog? We explore the benefits, risks, and scientific consensus behind this growing trend.
content:
The raw food diet (BARF) has gained massive popularity, but is it safe? 

**The Benefits:**
Proponents argue it leads to shinier coats, healthier skin, and higher energy levels.

**The Risks:**
Bacterial contamination (Salmonella, E. coli) is a real risk for both pets and owners. Nutritional imbalance is also common if not carefully formulated.

**Our Verdict:**
Consult with a veterinary nutritionist before switching. We offer personalized diet plans that can safely incorporate fresh foods.
author: Dr. Isabella Rossi

title: Puppy Socialization: The Critical Window
excerpt: Why the first 16 weeks of your puppy's life define their future behavior and how to make the most of it.
content:
Between 3 and 16 weeks of age, your puppy is in their critical socialization period. What they experience now shapes how they view the world forever.

**Checklist:**
- Meet 100 new people (safely)
- Walk on different surfaces (grass, concrete, wood)
- Hear different sounds (traffic, vacuum, doorbell)

Don't wait until they are fully vaccinated to start *safe* socialization. Carry them or use a stroller!
author: Pawly Team
